22#ifndef ISC_FILE_H
23#define ISC_FILE_H 1
24
25/*! \file isc/file.h */
26
27#include <stdio.h>
28
29#include <isc/lang.h>
30#include <isc/types.h>
31
32ISC_LANG_BEGINDECLS
33
34isc_result_t
35isc_file_settime(const char *file, isc_time_t *itime);
36
37isc_result_t
38isc_file_getmodtime(const char *file, isc_time_t *itime);
39/*!<
40 * \brief Get the time of last modification of a file.
41 *
42 * Notes:
43 *\li The time that is set is relative to the (OS-specific) epoch, as are
44 * all isc_time_t structures.
45 *
46 * Requires:
47 *\li file != NULL.
48 *\li time != NULL.
49 *
50 * Ensures:
51 *\li If the file could not be accessed, 'time' is unchanged.
52 *
53 * Returns:
54 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS
55 * Success.
56 *\li #ISC_R_NOTFOUND
57 * No such file exists.
58 *\li #ISC_R_INVALIDFILE
59 * The path specified was not usable by the operating system.
60 *\li #ISC_R_NOPERM
61 * The file's metainformation could not be retrieved because
62 * permission was denied to some part of the file's path.
63 *\li #ISC_R_EIO
64 * Hardware error interacting with the filesystem.
65 *\li #ISC_R_UNEXPECTED
66 * Something totally unexpected happened.
67 *
68 */
69
70isc_result_t
71isc_file_mktemplate(const char *path, char *buf, size_t buflen);
72/*!<
73 * \brief Generate a template string suitable for use with isc_file_openunique().
74 *
75 * Notes:
76 *\li This function is intended to make creating temporary files
77 * portable between different operating systems.
78 *
79 *\li The path is prepended to an implementation-defined string and
80 * placed into buf. The string has no path characters in it,
81 * and its maximum length is 14 characters plus a NUL. Thus
82 * buflen should be at least strlen(path) + 15 characters or
83 * an error will be returned.
84 *
85 * Requires:
86 *\li buf != NULL.
87 *
88 * Ensures:
89 *\li If result == #ISC_R_SUCCESS:
90 * buf contains a string suitable for use as the template argument
91 * to isc_file_openunique().
92 *
93 *\li If result != #ISC_R_SUCCESS:
94 * buf is unchanged.
95 *
96 * Returns:
97 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS Success.
98 *\li #ISC_R_NOSPACE buflen indicates buf is too small for the catenation
99 * of the path with the internal template string.
100 */
101
102
103isc_result_t
104isc_file_openunique(char *templet, FILE **fp);
105isc_result_t
106isc_file_openuniqueprivate(char *templet, FILE **fp);
107isc_result_t
108isc_file_openuniquemode(char *templet, int mode, FILE **fp);
109/*!<
110 * \brief Create and open a file with a unique name based on 'templet'.
111 *
112 * Notes:
113 *\li 'template' is a reserved work in C++. If you want to complain
114 * about the spelling of 'templet', first look it up in the
115 * Merriam-Webster English dictionary. (http://www.m-w.com/)
116 *
117 *\li This function works by using the template to generate file names.
118 * The template must be a writable string, as it is modified in place.
119 * Trailing X characters in the file name (full file name on Unix,
120 * basename on Win32 -- eg, tmp-XXXXXX vs XXXXXX.tmp, respectively)
121 * are replaced with ASCII characters until a non-existent filename
122 * is found. If the template does not include pathname information,
123 * the files in the working directory of the program are searched.
124 *
125 *\li isc_file_mktemplate is a good, portable way to get a template.
126 *
127 * Requires:
128 *\li 'fp' is non-NULL and '*fp' is NULL.
129 *
130 *\li 'template' is non-NULL, and of a form suitable for use by
131 * the system as described above.
132 *
133 * Ensures:
134 *\li If result is #ISC_R_SUCCESS:
135 * *fp points to an stream opening in stdio's "w+" mode.
136 *
137 *\li If result is not #ISC_R_SUCCESS:
138 * *fp is NULL.
139 *
140 * No file is open. Even if one was created (but unable
141 * to be reopened as a stdio FILE pointer) then it has been
142 * removed.
143 *
144 *\li This function does *not* ensure that the template string has not been
145 * modified, even if the operation was unsuccessful.
146 *
147 * Returns:
148 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS
149 * Success.
150 *\li #ISC_R_EXISTS
151 * No file with a unique name could be created based on the
152 * template.
153 *\li #ISC_R_INVALIDFILE
154 * The path specified was not usable by the operating system.
155 *\li #ISC_R_NOPERM
156 * The file could not be created because permission was denied
157 * to some part of the file's path.
158 *\li #ISC_R_IOERROR
159 * Hardware error interacting with the filesystem.
160 *\li #ISC_R_UNEXPECTED
161 * Something totally unexpected happened.
162 */
163
164isc_result_t
165isc_file_remove(const char *filename);
166/*!<
167 * \brief Remove the file named by 'filename'.
168 */
169
170isc_result_t
171isc_file_rename(const char *oldname, const char *newname);
172/*!<
173 * \brief Rename the file 'oldname' to 'newname'.
174 */
175
176isc_boolean_t
177isc_file_exists(const char *pathname);
178/*!<
179 * \brief Return #ISC_TRUE if the calling process can tell that the given file exists.
180 * Will not return true if the calling process has insufficient privileges
181 * to search the entire path.
182 */
183
184isc_boolean_t
185isc_file_isabsolute(const char *filename);
186/*!<
187 * \brief Return #ISC_TRUE if the given file name is absolute.
188 */
189
190isc_result_t
191isc_file_isplainfile(const char *name);
192/*!<
193 * \brief Check that the file is a plain file
194 *
195 * Returns:
196 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS
197 * Success. The file is a plain file.
198 *\li #ISC_R_INVALIDFILE
199 * The path specified was not usable by the operating system.
200 *\li #ISC_R_FILENOTFOUND
201 * The file does not exist. This return code comes from
202 * errno=ENOENT when stat returns -1. This code is mentioned
203 * here, because in logconf.c, it is the one rcode that is
204 * permitted in addition to ISC_R_SUCCESS. This is done since
205 * the next call in logconf.c is to isc_stdio_open(), which
206 * will create the file if it can.
207 *\li #other ISC_R_* errors translated from errno
208 * These occur when stat returns -1 and an errno.
209 */
210
211isc_boolean_t
212isc_file_iscurrentdir(const char *filename);
213/*!<
214 * \brief Return #ISC_TRUE if the given file name is the current directory (".").
215 */
216
217isc_boolean_t
218isc_file_ischdiridempotent(const char *filename);
219/*%<
220 * Return #ISC_TRUE if calling chdir(filename) multiple times will give
221 * the same result as calling it once.
222 */
223
224const char *
225isc_file_basename(const char *filename);
226/*%<
227 * Return the final component of the path in the file name.
228 */
229
230isc_result_t
231isc_file_progname(const char *filename, char *buf, size_t buflen);
232/*!<
233 * \brief Given an operating system specific file name "filename"
234 * referring to a program, return the canonical program name.
235 *
236 *
237 * Any directory prefix or executable file name extension (if
238 * used on the OS in case) is stripped. On systems where program
239 * names are case insensitive, the name is canonicalized to all
240 * lower case. The name is written to 'buf', an array of 'buflen'
241 * chars, and null terminated.
242 *
243 * Returns:
244 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS
245 *\li #ISC_R_NOSPACE The name did not fit in 'buf'.
246 */
247
248isc_result_t
249isc_file_template(const char *path, const char *templet, char *buf,
250 size_t buflen);
251/*%<
252 * Create an OS specific template using 'path' to define the directory
253 * 'templet' to describe the filename and store the result in 'buf'
254 * such that path can be renamed to buf atomically.
255 */
256
257isc_result_t
258isc_file_renameunique(const char *file, char *templet);
259/*%<
260 * Rename 'file' using 'templet' as a template for the new file name.
261 */
262
263isc_result_t
264isc_file_absolutepath(const char *filename, char *path, size_t pathlen);
265/*%<
266 * Given a file name, return the fully qualified path to the file.
267 */
268
269/*
270 * XXX We should also have a isc_file_writeeopen() function
271 * for safely open a file in a publicly writable directory
272 * (see write_open() in BIND 8's ns_config.c).
273 */
274
275isc_result_t
276isc_file_truncate(const char *filename, isc_offset_t size);
277/*%<
278 * Truncate/extend the file specified to 'size' bytes.
279 */
280
281isc_result_t
282isc_file_safecreate(const char *filename, FILE **fp);
283/*%<
284 * Open 'filename' for writing, truncating if necessary. Ensure that
285 * if it existed it was a normal file. If creating the file, ensure
286 * that only the owner can read/write it.
287 */
288
289isc_result_t
290isc_file_splitpath(isc_mem_t *mctx, char *path,
291 char **dirname, char **basename);
292/*%<
293 * Split a path into dirname and basename. If 'path' contains no slash
294 * (or, on windows, backslash), then '*dirname' is set to ".".
295 *
296 * Allocates memory for '*dirname', which can be freed with isc_mem_free().
297 *
298 * Returns:
299 * - ISC_R_SUCCESS on success
300 * - ISC_R_INVALIDFILE if 'path' is empty or ends with '/'
301 * - ISC_R_NOMEMORY if unable to allocate memory
302 */
303
304ISC_LANG_ENDDECLS
305
306#endif /* ISC_FILE_H */
